activities.title: 2-Minute Start (Tiny Action Kickoff)
activities.description: Name the single smallest physical action toward your top task (e.g., open doc, type title). Start a 120-second timer and do only that. This lowers activation energy (Tiny Habits), exploits the Zeigarnik effect, and jump-starts dopamine for momentum.

activities.title: 5-Minute If–Then Setup + Environment Reset
activities.description: Write one If–Then plan for the biggest expected obstacle (If X occurs, then I will Y). Clear your space: close extra tabs, silence phone, put it out of reach, open only needed files. This uses implementation intentions and stimulus control to prevent derailment.

activities.title: 10-Minute WOOP + Next 3 Micro-Steps
activities.description: Do WOOP: Wish (1 sentence), Outcome (why it matters), Obstacle (inner/outer), Plan (If obstacle, then action). Then list the next 3 micro-steps with verbs and a simple Definition of Done. Mental contrasting + if–then improves follow-through.

activities.title: 30-Minute Deep Work Sprint (25/5)
activities.description: Work 25 minutes on one deliverable; capture distractions on paper instead of switching; finish with a 5-minute break (move, water, sunlight). Use website/app blockers. This timebox minimizes attentional residue and boosts throughput.

howToAvoid: Go full-screen on the work app and keep only one tab/window.
Use a distraction list: when an urge arises, jot it down and return after the sprint.
Rewrite tasks as the next visible physical action (verb + object, e.g., 'Draft 3 bullet points for landing page').
Add a one-line Definition of Done before you start.
Place phone in another room or a timed box; enable Do Not Disturb/Focus mode.
Block social/news sites during sprints with app/website blockers.
Set an MVP bar: 'good enough to ship a draft in 25 minutes'.
Use a time cap: ship the draft at the end of the sprint, then iterate later.

avoids.toAvoid: Unbounded work sessions that drain willpower
howToAvoid: Always set a visible timer for each sprint and pre-schedule the stop.
When it gets tough, lower the bar by 50% and continue for 2 more minutes before deciding to quit.
Start the day with the 2-Minute Start on your priority before opening inbox/Slack.
Batch communications into 2–3 windows and keep them off during deep work.
Do a 60–90 second state change (quick walk, 10 squats, cold water splash) before restarting.
Use urge surfing: notice the urge like a wave, breathe for 90 seconds, and let it pass without acting.
Cap caffeine by mid-afternoon and anchor a consistent sleep window.
Use morning light exposure and a short walk to stabilize circadian alertness.

rewards.title: Physical micro-reward
rewards.desc: Before starting, picture standing up after the sprint, shoulders relaxing, taking a satisfying sip of your favorite drink, and a 2–3 minute sunlight walk. Feel the bodily ease.

rewards.title: Mental progress checkmark
rewards.desc: Visualize ticking a checkbox, moving a task card to 'Done', and watching your weekly progress bar advance. See the concrete artifact you created (draft, lines of code, sent email).

rewards.title: Emotional relief and pride
rewards.desc: Imagine the relief of having shipped the draft and the warm pride of keeping a promise to yourself. Hear yourself say, 'I did the hard part.'

rewards.title: Social acknowledgment
rewards.desc: See yourself posting a quick update to your team or customer and receiving a 'Nice work!' reaction or appreciative reply. Feel the connection and credibility gain.
